abstracts.cdata!:
The Yacyreta Hydroelectric Project is a
            joint venture between Argentina and Paraguay, who concluded
            a treaty for the Yacyreta Hydroelectric Dam, a joint
            undertaking, managed by a semi-autonomous bi-national
            entity. The Yacyreta Project extends more than two decades,
            and, its social and environmental parts are partly financed
            under both the Argentina, and Paraguay loans. This report
            concludes the Panel's investigation into allegations in
            the Request for Inspection submitted in May 2002. It
            adresses Bank environmental compliance issues raised by the
            complaint: the adequacy of environmental assessments, the
            relationship between the level of the reservoir and urban
            flooding, and ground water levels, the water-related health
            problems, and, the location and design of the sewage
            treatment plant. It finds the environmental screening
            process was appropriate. However, on reviewing the
            environmental assessments and resettlement plans, it was
            found these to be very inadequate, not in compliance with
            the Bank's Operational Directive OD 4.01. It considers
            the biophysical environment, and urban and peri-urban
            environments, finding that both environmental and social
            assessments should have anticipated the induced effects
            associated with the Project, that construction of the
            Yacyreta dam has a negligible effect on the water level of
            the Parana river at Encarnacion, especially in times of
            flood, that the reservoir is frequently operated under
            excessive water production levels, and that this is not
            consistent with neither the loan agreement, nor the Third
            Owners Agreement, as amended. Moreover, the Panel confirms
            that flooding makes the drinking water unsafe, however, it
            finds that the alleged causal relationship between the level
            of the Yacyreta reservoir, and pollution of wells and
            flooding of latrines is not correct, while the existence of
            the monitoring program was verified, reviewed, and no
            evidence contradicting the findings was found, and, confirms
            that the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare of Paraguay
            adequately monitors the incidence of both disease, and
            disease vectors. Importantly, the Panel finds that
            responsibility for the cost of connection to the sewer
            system may become a significant source of conflict, and
            needs urgent attention of Bank Management. The Panel finds
            persuasive evidence of erroneous omissions on the number of
            people present at the 1990 census, thus making them
            ineligible for Project compensation and resettlement
            benefits, and, that this sole basis for restoration of
            income does not satisfy OD 4.30's requirement for many
            affected people, and, that grievance mechanisms were neither
            in compliance with the directive.
